docs.lead_paragraph: AT the World Access Assistance Center in Richmond, which answers calls for help from people with trip insurance, nurses and a physician conduct "morning rounds" on the day's medical cases in a conference phone call. The patients are scattered around the world. Their progress is assessed after talks with medical personnel where the clients are being treated. Although there is no air of emergency about the Center, a day here gives a snapshot of what befalls travelers and how problems are handled.

docs.lead_paragraph: The 11th international AIDS meeting opens here on Sunday with leading researchers' hopes as high as the sun-drenched mountains surrounding this Canadian seaport. Remarkable gains in using combinations of costly new and old drugs promise to slow the progression of AIDS, if not stop it in its tracks, and to allow many people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to live longer and healthier lives, the researchers said in interviews.

headline.main: AIDS Meeting: Signs of Hope, And Obstacles

docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago, Todd and Melissa Greenberg, who had moved to New York City from the Midwest, started looking for a house in Westchester County. The Greenbergs, both of whom work in the health-care industry, knew they earned enough to buy a house but were concerned about getting a mortgage without a substantial down payment. "We were caught up in the New York City catch-22," said Mr. Greenberg, 31. "The one where you pay so much for rent that you can't save enough money for a down payment so that you can stop paying so much for rent."

headline.main: Down Payment Hurdle Is Getting Lower

docs.lead_paragraph: THE academic and business career of Dr. Arnold K. Weinstein has stretched from New York to Australia with posts in Europe in between, but now he has a job closer to his home in New Rochelle. Since March 1 he has been the president of Berkeley College, Westchester campus, in White Plains.

headline.main: College That Keeps Eye on the Job Market

docs.lead_paragraph: ALREADY, when you make a first impression, you are preparing the groove for a memory. And so I will remember Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, world expert in the scientific use of chimpanzees, standing in a doorway, in a stiff rather military dress jacket with brass buttons, with a portable telephone in each hand, his tall body at peace somehow with the low ceilings and walls of this early 19th century whaler's cottage in Orient. I did not know how I would feel about the moral issues involved in his kind of animal testing. He had done some of the ground-breaking work that allowed monkeys and apes to survive and to breed in a medical testing environment. He also was a central figure in a significant libel case, defending the right of letters to the editor to the protection of the First Amendment. And he was also a key person in a dispute with New York University, which gave his laboratory in Sterling Forest, N.Y., to his arch foe in the world of animal experimentation and dismissed him from his post as director.

headline.main: In the Maelstrom of Animal Medical Studies

docs.lead_paragraph: As Todd Hall was arraigned today on charges of involuntary manslaughter for a fire on Wednesday that killed eight people at a fireworks store, he giggled like a delighted child and mugged for the cameras. Mr. Hall's behavior today and on Wednesday -- when investigators said he ignited a fire by lighting a box of firecrackers at the Ohio River Fireworks store in Scottown -- may be explained in the lobotomy he underwent as a teen-ager after falling off a skateboard and injuring his head.

headline.main: Man Charged in Store Inferno Had Lobotomy as a Teen-Ager

docs.lead_paragraph: A big jump last month in hourly earnings, reported yesterday by the Labor Department, suggests that the wage stagnation plaguing so many Americans may be lifting, at least temporarily. The June number by itself does not make that case, although the rise of 9 cents, to $11.82, in the average hourly pay of 83 million nonmanagement production workers is the biggest one-month cash increase on record, and the biggest percentage increase since September 1983. As any labor economist will say, this monthly number jumps around a lot. What is striking, however, is the trend.

headline.main: Hourly Wage Jumps for 2d Straight Month

docs.lead_paragraph: With hospitals laying off record numbers of employees and falling behind in paying their bills, officials in New York's health care industry are contemplating something once considered unthinkable here: allowing public, profit-making companies to own hospitals in the state. New York is the only state in the nation that bars such companies from owning and operating hospitals, and even mention of the possibility was once regarded as taboo.

headline.main: A Move to Hospitals-for-Profit Gaining Support in New York

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The plan that Gov. George Pataki is negotiating with legislative leaders to replace New York State's outdated system of regulated hospital rates with market-driven prices appears sound. The plan would reap the low costs and innovation of competition without sacrificing the ample financing of indigent care and medical training that exists now. Under current law, Albany requires that insurers pay hospital rates that are high enough to cover not only the cost of treating their enrollees but also the cost of treating uninsured patients and, for teaching hospitals, the cost of training residents. But once Albany allows rates to fall, insurers would not voluntarily pay for charity care and physician training that does not directly benefit their subscribers.

headline.main: The State's Promising Hospital Rate Plan
